image_matrix.caption: My new little friend in Quito (1989).

Pichincha is an active volcano outside Quito, Ecuador. This Edward Whymper woodcut of 1892 shows three of Whymper's guides near the summit. Whymper was a famous naturalist, climber, and artist who climbed extensively in the Alps and the Andes. In 1880, he was the first climber to ascend a high altitude peak, in this case Chimborazo (20,400'). His signature appears in the lower left corner. See the delightful accounts of his climbs and travels in Travels Amongst the Great Andes of the Equator. R. Villarreal Collection.
Pichincha volcano summit (15,700', 4790 m).
This photo captures the 1999 eruption of Pichincha Volcano. I stood on the summit 12 years before this! Courtesy of Wikipedia.

El Cayambe (18,996', 5790 m) sits northeast of Quito. Its distinction is that the equator lies right on its southern slopes. We got this close to the peak before the guides determined that the entire lower portion of the Whymper route had been obliterated by avalanches. We pushed on to Cotopaxi.
Upon our departure from El Cayambe, I found another little friend, this one walking her dog.
Original 1892 Whymper woodcut of a puma approaching Whymper's tent on El Cayambe at 14,462' (4408 m). R. Villarreal Collection.
On the descent of El Cayambe, one of the pack animals slipped and fell over a precipice into the void below. Original 1892 Edward Whymper woodcut. R. Villarreal Collection.
Base Camp on Cotopaxi -- the Jose Rivas hut at 15,500' (4720 m).
Cotopaxi (19,347', 5897 m).
Another view of the Cotopaxi summit, this one higher on the route.
Whymper wood engraving dated 1892 of the Cotopaxi summit crater. R. Villarreal Collection.
On the return from the fog choked Cotopaxi summit, the mists lift to reveal the rich Ecuadorian countryside.
More stunning views from the flanks of Cotopaxi.
And more.
A section of the valley walls surrounding Banos, a small town near Tungurahua peak. It resembles Yosemite Valley, with numerous waterfalls that cascade into the valley below.
On the way from Banos to the Tungurahua staging area to rent our pack animals.
Pack horse for lugging our gear to a refugio on the slopes of Tungurahua volcano (16,475', 5022 m); next day it was too windy to climb.
The Tungurahua hut at 13,000' (4000 m). The wind was blasting the next morning so viciously that we cancelled an attempt on the summit.
This same Tungurahua erupting in April, 2011; the beautiful town of Banos is off to the left.
Another picture of the eruption.
We're on the way to the Carrel hut on Chimborazo (in the distance). Photo taken from Guarandas.

1899 original halftone print of Chimborazo by The Werner Company. This image is from Guarandas, very near the spot where I took the picture in the previous image. In both, the Whymper route to the summit is out of sight, over the ridge on the left skyline. R. Villarreal Collection.
This wood-engraving hunting scene most likely was carried out in the area of the previous picture of Chimborazo, near Guarandas. It's another Whymper work dated 1885. R. Villarreal Collection.
The Louis Carrel hut on Chimborazo, at 15,912' (4850 m). Carrel was one of Whymper's climbing guides in Ecuador.
A look down to the Carrel hut on the way up to the Base Camp location of the Whymper hut.
The Whymper hut at 16,404' (5000 m). Courtesy Summit Post.

A view of Chimborazo from the Whymper hut. The route follows the ridge to the right. Once above the rock and ice outcropping in the center of the picture, the route traverses to the left skyline and follows the glacier to the summit.
On the top; I'm on the left with our Ecuadorian guide.
Original 1892 Edward Whymper woodcut as he and his guides try to erect their tent low on the slopes of Chimborazo. R. Villarreal Collection.
Another Whymper engraving showing climbers, at 17,450' (5319 m), above the site of today's Whymper hut as they work their way across the ridge outside camp. R. Villarreal Collection.
Whymper's engraving of the scene higher on the route, at 18,500' (5640 m). R. Villarreal Collection.
Whymper engraving of the route as they close on the summit. R. Villarreal Collection.

Louis Carrel contracted frostbite on the climb. A litter was rigged up and he was carried to the nearby town of Ambato for medical treatment Another 1892 woodcut by Edward Whymper. R. Villarreal Collection.
La Paz, with Illimani in the distance (1991).
1931 original photogravure by Atlantis-Verlag of La Paz, with Illimani in the distance. R. Villarreal Collection.
Our llama arrieros load the animals for the hike into Condoriri and Pequeno Alpamayo.
On the way to Alpamayo.
Pequeno Alpamayo (17,558', 5352 m).
A view to the west.
We inch our way up.
On the top.
On the top with a rope mate.
Cerro Huayna Potosi (19,968', 6086 m).
One rope team nears the summit, out of sight to the right.
We approach a small village on the way to Base Camp. Illimani in distance (21,122', 6438 m).
Above the little village.
Another view.
We near Base Camp.
On the summit.
Our descent down the mountain.

The Tiwanaku (or Tiahuanaco) complex, looking north. Tiahuanaco is a Pre-Colombian archaeological site in western Bolivia. It was the capital of an empire that extended into present-day Peru and Chile, flourishing from AD 300 to AD 1000. The temple complex of Kalasasaya is in the center of the scene. The following pictures show much of the present-day site.
Staircase and entrance door of the Kalasasaya Temple.
Interior walls of the Semi-subterranean Temple with the \"embedded heads\" on its walls.
Another view of the Semi-subterranean Temple courtyard.
The Ponce monolith in the Kalasasaya complex.
The Gateway of the Sun. It stands 10 feet high and 13 feet wide.
General Orientation map showing peaks chronicled in Clawing for the Stars: A Solo Climber in the Highest Andes.
This map shows many of the peaks and other places of interest mentioned in the chapters. Ojos del Salado is south of the Great Plateau on the border with Argentina.
Giancarlo at the rear of his truck with James on the roof.
The scene from the Pass, with Laguna Santa Rosa below and Tres Cruces in the distance.
The Santa Rosa Refugio with Giancarlo's Land Cruiser alongside.
Giancarlo on the way into the old Carabinero Station, which has been relocated to the shores of Laguna Verde since this photo was taken in 1992.
Our Base Camp at 14,800' (4510 m); in the distance, El Muerto (21,286', 6488 m) is on the left and Ojos on the right.
A storm buries Ojos. R. Villarreal Collection.

image_matrix.caption: Early morning scene with the moon still visible.
On the road to the Atacama Refugio.
Refugio Atacama (16,730', 5100 m). Although it looks quite spartan, it's actually quite comfortable.
A stream fed by snowfields higher on the mountain flows by Atacama.
The road leading to Refugio Tejos (18,860', 5750 m). It's hard to believe a road exists this high.
Another shot of the road.
On the way to the Tejos Refugio with the Atacama far below. A road this high is unheard of! R. Villarreal Collection.
image_matrix.label: A2

image_matrix.caption: The Refugio is right behind me. The imposing northern face of Ojos del Salado (22,609', 6891 m).
Another view from Tejos.
Another view. The sphinx-like paw of the First Step is partially in view. One may discern the other four steps above proceeding towards the summit. I placed my camp above Tejos on the First Step.
My First Step camp.
Another shot; El Muerto in the distance.
View of El Muerto from the Third Step.
Looking back down the Steps.
Another view: the First Step quite a ways down.

On top of the Fifth Step looking over at El Muerto (21,247', 6476 m). El Fraile (19,614', 5978 m) is in the mid-distance with Incahuasi (21,651', 6599 m) farther on. Summit is behind me and a little higher.

View from the summit looking south/southwest. In the near distance on the right is Cazadero (aka Walter Penck). At 21,838' (6656 m) it is the ninth highest peak. Farther on to the left is the darkened mass of Nacimiento (21,126', 6439 m). In the far distance is Pissis (22,287', 6793 m), the third highest peak.
From the summit: Tres Cruces rises in the west, with Central on the left and Sur on the right.
James signs the summit register. This wasn't exactly his best side!
Looking into the mouth of the summit crater.
Self photo after James leaves.
We descend by way of the massive north face; the Tejos refugio is barely visible far below.
A magnificent sunset from our Base Camp.
We depart the Ojos region on the return to Copiapo. Barrancas Blancas on the right, Ojos del Salado in the center, and El Muerto to the left. R. Villarreal Collection.
